string.i: Select a cipher to enter the encoder

resources.string: The Caesar cipher, also known as the shift cipher, is one of simplest encryption schemes. It works by substituting each letter in the plaintext with another letter X fixed positions down the alphabet. For example, if you rotated \'A\' by 2, it would become \'C\'. The alphabet also wraps around, so if you shift a \'Z\' by 2, it will become a B. The technique utilized to decode a Caesar cipher is to perform the encoding rotation again but in the opposite direction. If you shift by 3 to encode, you would have to shift by -3 to decode. Due to the simplicity of this encryption scheme, it provides basically no security as it can be easily cracked using a brute force attack.
You must either provide a rotate amount or generate one before running the cipher.\n\nThe rotate amount can be any whole positive or negative numbers.

A substitution cipher is an encryption method in which each letter in the plaintext is matched with a different letter in the cipher text. It requires an \"alphabet\" to be created, where the first letter corresponds to A, the second one to B, and so on. If your alphabet provided was CAT… then all A\'s would map to C, all B\'s to A, and all C\'s to T. No two letters in the plaintext can map to the same letter in the ciphertext, so each letter must be used only once while creating the alphabet. While substitution ciphers are more difficult to brute force, one can crack them by performing Frequency Analysis to study the frequency of letters in a ciphertext and attempt to map them to letters in the real English alphabet.
You must provide an input string to perform frequency analysis.
Your must provide a valid alphabet containing all 26 letters or generate one before running the cipher.

The Vigenère cipher is an encryption scheme in which each letter of the plaintext is encoded with a different rotating Caesar cipher. The provided key provides the rotate amounts, and is repeated until the length of the plaintext. If your key was BAG, it would rotate the first character by 1, the second one by 0, and the third one by 6 (then repeat). Please note that rotating by A is the same thing as rotating by 0, as that is the 0th index of the alphabet. Vigenère ciphers are very difficult to crack without knowing the key. However, if you know the key length, you could split the letters into groups based on their indices and perform Frequency Analysis on each group to try to determine the key.
You must provide a valid key (of any length) or generate one before running the cipher

An Atbash cipher is another simple encryption method that is based off of a substitution cipher. It works by taking the alphabet and mapping the inverse to itself so the first letter becomes the last letter. In this cipher, A\'s become Z\'s, and B\'s become Y\'s. This scheme is very simple to decode as you just perform the same algorithm again to reverse the text back to the original. Due to the simplicity of this encryption scheme it provides practically no communications security and can be cracked almost instantly upon recognizing it was used.
